lesson.title: Data Strategy
lesson.summary: Putting everything together to create the right data strategy for your situation.

files.name: Knapsack Data Strategy MVP Proposal Template

atoms.title: Lesson Intro Heading
atoms.text: # Data Strategy

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 01 Lesson Intro
Lesson Outline Recap
atoms.text:
In this lesson we will cover: 
- Processing of data with ETL versus ELT 
- Data storage options
    - How to choose the best option between a Database, a Data Warehouse or Data Lake
- Data strategy 
    - When should you build and when should you buy?
    - Open source vs commercial 
    - Cloud Vs. On-prem.
    - Insource Vs. outsource the development of tech. 
- Security and compliance.

**For all exercises in this course you will be using a spreadsheet, [Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises], and document, [Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises Template], provided in the Resources section of the classroom.
** 

## Important Keep a Copy of your Exercise Responses in the Template Document
It is highly recommended that as you complete the open-ended exercises in this course, you should keep them in the provided template document to refer back to throughout the course. It will be extremely useful as you complete the Final Exercise in the course: Knapsack Data Strategy MVP in the Data Strategy section of this course. You can still copy and paste your responses into the text boxes on each page in the course for each exercise if you wish.

atoms.title: ETL Heading
atoms.text: # ETL (Extract, Transform and Load)

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 02 Introduction To ETL
What is ETL
atoms.text:
## What is ETL
**ETL stands for Extraction, Transformation and Loading** of data. In this type of processing pipeline, data is first extracted from various sources, after that transformed and loaded to a Database or Data Warehouse, from where it is pulled for analysis.

- **[Data processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_processing)** is, generally, the collection and manipulation of items of data to produce meaningful information.
- **[Data extraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_extraction)** is the act or process of retrieving data out of data sources for further data processing or data storage. 
- **In the [data transformation stage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load)**, a series of rules or functions are applied to the extracted data in order to prepare it for loading into the end target.
- **The load phase**: loads the data into the end target, which can be any data store including a simple delimited flat file or a data warehouse.

atoms.title: Batch Text
atoms.text:
**Batch processing**:  

Processing massive data with scheduled jobs at once is batch processing. 

This works really well in scenarios where  periodic processing of data is needed. A good example is processing salaries of employees every week or Ecommerce platforms generating invoices for their vendors every month.

atoms.title: Stream Text
atoms.text:
**Stream Processing**: 

Another type of processing is done in almost real-time, as data comes it is processed.

Or as the streams of data come together, they are processed. Stream processing examples would be payment processing and fraud detection. These two have to be done in real time as they happen.

question.prompt: In the ETL processing the sequence of Extraction,Transformation and Loading is **not** important.

answers.text: True
False

question.prompt: Which of the following are **True** about Stream and Batch Processing?

answers.text: If you need to process all of your data once a week stream processing is great.
If you need to process data as it comes again stream processing is the answer.
You are an online learning site for preschoolers. You want to send an activity log to parents every month. You should use stream processing.
A fashion blogger and own a styling website. You want to capture trends in real-time from social media platforms and appropriately highlight articles on your site. You should use stream processing.

atoms.title: Challenges with ETL Heading
atoms.text: # Challenges with ETL

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 03 Challenges With ETL
Challenges with ETL
atoms.text:
### ETL Challenges
Some of the challenges with ETL include:
- Processing data before loading it. 
- Amount of data generated in an enterprise is increasing 
- Transformation code can be millions of lines. This might make it really hard to scale an ETL pipeline. 
- Transforming all the data before loading might be an overkill. 
    - *Example*: you might not need to process all the event data generated on the website at once. 

### Challenges continued: 
**Different Data Types**

Entity data needs to be treated very differently than event data. Similarly, structured data, semi-structured data, or unstructured data. All have specific needs. ETLs work best with **entity** and **structured data**. Implementing ETL for other data types can be challenging. 

**Different Data Sources**

Data sources are varied and spread across. We have data on-prem and in the cloud. We have constant streams of data, and we have batches of data. With ETL pipelines it might be difficult and slow to bring all this data together.

question.prompt: ETL Pipelines work best with

answers.text: Structured and Entity Data
Unstructured and Entity Data

question.prompt: Which of the following poses challenges for ETLs

answers.text: Data is of all types- structured, unstructured or semi-structured
Data is spread across Cloud and on-premise
Data is of entity type and of event type
Data might need Stream or Batch Processing

atoms.title: When to use ETL Heading
atoms.text: # When to Use ETL

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 04 When To Use ETL
When to use ETL
atoms.text:
### When to use ETLs
It is very clear from our discussion that ETLS works best in scenarios where data is structured and of an entity type. A few examples would be:
- Online transaction data
- Customer records
- Inventory records

question.prompt: ETLs are best suited to data infrastructure if data volumes are huge

answers.text: True
False

question.prompt: ETLs can be used if:

answers.text: Data is produced in a one format and is consumed in a different format.
Data volumes are not huge.
Data is transactional in nature.
Data is relational.

atoms.title: ELT Heading
atoms.text: # ELTs

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 05 Introduction To ELT
What is ELT
atoms.text:
### What is an ELT
In ELT, pipeline data can be extracted from various data sources. This data could be structured, unstructured, or semi-structured data. Data is loaded in data storage such as Data Lake. Transformation is still required before data can be used. This happens after data has been loaded in Data Lake.

question.prompt: ELT is

answers.text: When you extract data after it is loaded.
When you transform data after it is loaded.
When you transform data before it is extracted or loaded.

atoms.title: Challenges with ELT Heading
atoms.text: # Challenges with ELT

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 06 Challenges With ELT
Challenges with ELT
atoms.text:
### ELT Challenges
- **Expensive**: ELT pipelines generally deal with huge volumes of structured and unstructured data. Scalability is a necessity for ELT pipelines. If data storage and data processing are a concern, ELT might not be the solution. 
- **New**: ELT is less mature and less reliable than ETL. It is still evolving; it is hard to find resources with expertise in this domain. 
- **Corner Cases**: ETL requires stringent standards to avoid security risk and removing, masking or encrypting data might be harder

question.prompt: Which of the following is not true for ELTs

answers.text: Less mature tech
Hard to find resources
Needs lots of storage
Better than ETLs

atoms.title: When to use ELT Heading
atoms.text: # When to Use ELT

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 07 When To Use ELT
when to use elt image
atoms.caption: Example of when to use ELTs: Big Data
atoms.alt: Example of when to use ELTs: Big Data

atoms.title: When to use ELT
atoms.text:
### When should you use ELT?

**Source and Target Database are of the same type**

One use case of ELT could be when the source and target database are of the same type. An example being an Oracle source and Oracle target. There would be no reason to do unnecessary processing before loading data from the source Oracle database to the destination Oracle database?

**Huge Data Volumes**


When data volumes are huge, you do not want to process anything and everything under the Sun. This is the reality for most enterprises. Data volumes are huge; hence ELTs might work better as they wonâ€™t become bottlenecks. 

**Data is unstructured or mixed structure**


ELTs are better when you have a mix of data types. For a use case of customer sentiment analysis where you might have data such as user reviews, emails, customer care chat scripts, ELT will work better.

question.prompt: When should you use ELT

answers.text: When data is highly structured and organized
Source and destination are of same type
Data volumes are really high
Data is a mix of all data types

atoms.title: Choose Your Processing Elements Heading
atoms.text: At Knapsack, we are building an OLAP ecosystem. What that means is we will have a Data Warehouse and an OLAP server on top of it.

atoms.title: Choose Your Elements Quiz
tasks: Knowing what we know so far, what are all of the sources of data that should feed into Knapsack's OLAP.

Do we need an ETL or ELT pipeline? Why?
For the above use case can you create an illustration of a data pipeline which has following: Data Producers, Data Processing elements and Data Consumer in an OLAP Data Warehouse.

atoms.title: Choose Your Processing Elements Solution Heading
atoms.text: # Data Processing Strategy Solution

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 08 Choose Your Processing Elements
Choose Your Processing Elements
atoms.text:
Putting everything together using the image above.
Here is what our data pipeline might look like. 

We have data sources
- OLTP DB
- Simply Accounting DB
- Just Sale DB

We have our ETL processes running, and we have data being loaded to an OLAP data warehouse. 


Data from here goes to an OLAP server, where it is used for business reporting and building historical sales trends.

atoms.title: Data Storage Heading
atoms.text: # Data Storage

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 09 Database Definition
Database Definition
atoms.text:
A **[database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database)** is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.

A **[data warehouse](https://aws.amazon.com/data-warehouse/)** is a central repository of information that can be analyzed to make better-informed decisions. Data flows into a data warehouse from transactional systems, relational Databases, and other sources, typically on a regular cadence. 

To summarize, Data Warehouses are required to store large quantities of historical data and provide fast, complex queries across all the data, mostly using OLAPS. Databases focus on storing current transactional data to enable fast access to specific data for business processes. This is how OLTPs work.

### Types of Database
Databases can be categorized into two major classes SQL Databases and No SQL Databases. 

**SQL Databases** are the classic category of Databases they store data in tables, data is relational in nature and can be queried using SQL. **Schemas** need to be defined. A **Schema** is nothing but an organization of data as a blueprint of how the  Databases is constructed. 

Common SQL Databases are [MS SQL Server](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server), [Oracle](https://www.oracle.com/database/) and [MySQL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySQL) 

**No SQL Databases**
- **Document oriented**

Document oriented Databases do not have a fixed schema. Data is stored in JSON documents, each document can have different fields common examples are [Mongo DB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MongoDB), [CouchDB](https://docs.couchdb.org/) or [Documentdb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_DocumentDB)
- **Columnar Databases**

In columnar Databases data is stored in columns instead of how it is stored in rows in relational DBs. Column based queries can run fast on these DBs. It is much easier in columnar Databases to add columns than their counterpart relational DBs. One common example of the most popular columnar  Databases is [Cassandra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cassandra).

- **Key-Value Databases**

In key-value Databases, values are stored with unique keys. These Databases are much simpler and capable of reads and write. Examples of key-value Databases are [Redis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redis) and [Amazon DynamoDB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_DynamoDB).

- **Graph Databases**

In graph Databases, data is stored as a network. These Databases focus on connections between data points and are used for the analysis of relationships between data points. Examples of graph Databases are [Infinite Graph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InfiniteGraph) and [Neo4j](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InfiniteGraph).

question.prompt: A database is

answers.text: a  physical storage unit
storage that gets data from multiple applications
A storage for OLAP systems, because it gets data from various places
a structured set of data held in a computer, especially one that is accessible in various ways

question.prompt: Which of the following are true?

answers.text: NoSQL Databases are great for relational datasets
Document oriented Databases do not need fixed Schema
SQL Databases can be queried using structured query language
In columnar Databases it is hard to change columns

question.prompt: Which of the following are not true?

answers.text: Database and Data warehouse are different names for the same thing.
Data warehouse get data from multiple applications
Database are primarily used for business analytics
Data warehouse are great for OLTP applications

atoms.title: Database Selection Criterion Heading
atoms.text: # Database Selection Criterion

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 10 Database Selection Criterion
Database Selection Criterion Recap
atoms.text:
### Choosing the right Database

Here are some tips. 
- Look at the possible structure of your data? 
    - clearly relational such as transactional data
    - can it be mapped to key-value pairs like user comments or ratings?
- What is the size of the data? 
    - Big data or regular data. 
- What are the latency requirements?
    - used for reporting where data can be made available in minutes or hours 
    - Is it needed for real-time use cases such as upsell/cross-sell? 
- What are the core requirements of this DB? 
    - are the operations read-heavy or write-heavy 
    - will it be needed for search operations 

### SQL Databases or Relational DB
- Most mature and stable category of Databases -> Security
- Structured Data
- Financial applications or defense

### Document Oriented
- Schema Free
- Semi-structured  or Unstructured Data
- Content Management System: WordPress

### Columnar DB
- [Eventual Consistency](https://hackernoon.com/eventual-vs-strong-consistency-in-distributed-Database-282fdad37cf7)
- Query on subset of Column
- Data Science

### Key Value
- Simple key-value data
- Unstructured Data
- Customer Reviews

### Graph
- Graph like data
- Connections, nearest neighbor -> Focus on relationships
- Social Networks

question.prompt: Which of the following is not a database selection criterion

answers.text: Structure of data generated
Timeliness requirements
When is data generated - Monday vs Friday.

question.prompt: Which of the following are something to consider for a database selection criterion

answers.text: Structure of data generated
Timeliness requirements
Size of the data
Use case of the database

atoms.title: Data Warehouse Heading
atoms.text: # Data Warehouses

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 11 Data Warehouse
Data Warehouse
atoms.text:
#### Quick Reminder:
A **[data warehouse](https://aws.amazon.com/data-warehouse/)** is a central repository of information that can be analyzed to make better-informed decisions. Data flows into a data warehouse from transactional systems, relational databases, and other sources, typically on a regular cadence.

### Advantages
- Data consolidated at one place
- Speed
- Enriched data -> Better Business Intelligence
- Better decision making
- Improved Data Quality

### Disadvantages/Limitations
- Could be Costly
- Requires continuous cleaning, transformation and data integration
- Not helpful for real-time decision making
- Once implemented adding a new data source might be challenging

question.prompt: A data warehouse is not...

answers.text: A central repository of data
A network connecting Multiple Database across the organization
A storage that can be used to analyze data and make informed decisions
A place where data from all other Database or data sources might come

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 12 When To Use Data Warehouse Heading
When Data Warehouse
atoms.text:
## When to use Data Warehouse

- Multiple Database across the organization
- Large Database
- Lots of historical data. 
- DWHs are best for data mining in such scenarios. 
- Market research analysis. When large volumes of data are needed to do in-depth analysis with multiple dimensions of data help
- User behavior analysis needs a large volume of data, and data is needed from multiple sources.

question.prompt: When should you use a Data Warehouse...

answers.text: When data needs to be combined from various Database
When large volumes of data needs to be analyzed
When data needs to be analyzed on multiple dimensions
When you need to process huge historical data

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 13 Data Lake Heading
Data Lake
atoms.text:
## Data Lakes

A **[data lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_lake)** is a system or repository of data stored in its natural/raw format,usually object blobs or files. 

Broken down the definition of what data lake is:
- A Repository of Data that Stores data in its natural form 
- Usually a single store of all enterprise data 
- Used for reporting, visualization, advanced analytics, and machine learning 
- Has structured, semi-structured and unstructured data

### Advantages

- A vast amount of data can be stored. 
- It can be
    - Structured 
    - Semi-structured  
    - Unstructured data 
- Processing before loading not required
- Highly Agile

### Disadvantages/Limitations
- Maturing Technology
- Data Governance
- Low-cost storage might encourage unnecessary data accumulation
- Privacy Issues

question.prompt: Which of the following is true for data lakes...

answers.text: It has a long and complex definition, but is a simple concept.
Data can be stored as it comes and does not need to be processed.
Is good for all kinds of data - structured, unstructured or semi-structured.
Is a relatively new concept

atoms.title: When  DL Heading
atoms.text: # When to use Data Lake

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 14 When To Use Data Lake Heading
Recap
atoms.text:
## When to use a Data Lake

- Experimental Analysis

Data lakes can be used for experimental analysis of data, where you are still not sure and want to have a proof of concept before investing in an end-to-end data pipeline. ELTs make it easy to use Data lakes for such experimental analysis. 

-  Cybersecurity 

Cybersecurity data collection and analysis is a great use case of data lakes. Any enterprise devices such as laptops, servers, cloud computing devices, and virtual systems all are vulnerable. Add connected devices to this mix. It becomes a big data problem that can be solved using Data lakes. 

- Customer Data Platform

Data Lakes can be used to build customer data platforms to provide rich customer insights. Data for such platforms can come from various sources such as 
- customer profile Databases
- web and mobile events
- brick and mortar systems
- loyalty systems
- service center data 

This data can be of any type of structured, semi-structured, or unstructured. Data Lakes work best for such use cases.

question.prompt: When should you use Data Lake

answers.text: If it is not completely clear what data needs to be used.
When data needs to be collected from very many sources, and is of all types.
When ELT is the best processing strategy
When you have big data problems

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 15 Data Warehouse Vs Data Lake Heading
dl vs dwh image
atoms.caption: Key Differences Between Data Warehouses and Data Lakes
atoms.alt: Key Differences Between Data Warehouses and Data Lakes

atoms.title: DW v DL Image
atoms.caption: When should you use DWH and when you should use DL?
atoms.alt: When should you use DWH and when you should use DL?

atoms.title: Data Warehouse vs Data Lake
atoms.text:
## Data Warehouse vs. Data Lake

When should you use Data Warehouses, and when should you use Data Lakes?
#### Type of Data

When you have unstructured and structured data from various company data, sources use a data lake. When you have Historical data that has been structured to fit a relational database schema, use Data Warehouses.

#### Purpose

When you need cost-effective big data storage, use a Data Lake. When you need to store data to run analytics for business decisions, use Data Warehouses.

#### Users

Data Lake users are often data scientists and engineers, whereas Data Wharehouse users are data analysts and business analysts.

#### Workload
Data Lakes are suitable for storing massive data and big data analytics, like deep learning and real-time analytics. Data Warehouses are ideal for a smaller set of data compared to DL and are used for typical read-only queries that aggregate or summarize data.

#### Size
Data Lakes store all data that might be used and can take up to petabytes! Data Warehouses store only data relevant to the analysis.

#### Neither/Both?
Sometimes neither or both are better, while there are specific scenarios for each one, most enterprises adopt a hybrid approach. A business may catch all their data in a data lake and build ETL on top of it to feed DWH. For a small business, you might not need either.

question.prompt: Which of the following is True for Data Warehouses(DWHs) and Data Lakes(DLs)?

answers.text: The main data consumers for DWHs are data scientists and for DLs are business analysts
For DLs the storage is cheaper so that whatever data we want can be stored. Comparatively DWHs are expensive where only required and relevant data is stored.
DWHs are more agile compared to DLs.
DWHs are best when data requirements are clearly defined and data is not unstructured or semi-structured. DLs can be used in other cases.

atoms.title: Data Elements for Knapsack
atoms.positive_feedback: Thanks for completing that, check out the next page to see how your answers compare.

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 16 Choose Your Data Storage Elements Solution
Build vs Buy Heading
atoms.text: # Build vs Buy

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 17 Introduction & Build Vs Buy
Build vs Buy
atoms.text:
### When to Build
When should you build?
- When time commitments are critical, and vendors are not able to honor that. 
- You should build if the total cost of building, including development, testing, configuration, and scaling, along with talent and infrastructure, is much lower. 
- If a deep understanding of your business is needed. 
- You should also build when the costs of customization are huge. 
- It is always best to build for reasons of strategic importance that might provide you a competitive advantage. 

### When To Buy
When should you buy? 
- If it will take you too long to build.
- When the overall cost, including Licensing, Implementation, Integration, Customization, support, and infrastructure is much lower. 
- It is always good to buy market-available solutions for problems that are common across enterprises. For example, HR solutions. 
- If the problems have already been solved and there are market leaders available with solutions. For example, buying cloud storage on AWS or on Azure would be better than building it. 
- Buying some of the tech solutions will help you scale more quickly and reduce your speed to market.

### Additional Resources
[Uber Under Invested in Technology](https://www.zdnet.com/article/uber-we-under-invested-in-technology)

question.prompt: Which of the following are true?

answers.text: Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) is an important piece when deciding to Build or Buy, and can comprise of different costs for Build and different for Buy
It is always very easy to hire people and hence that is not critical to a Build versus Buy decision
If it is related to creating a differentiation in the market or value proposition, you should lean towards Building
Building in-house is important if you want to scale. Buying from outside might slow you down.

atoms.title: Open Source vs Commercial Heading
atoms.text: # Open Source vs Commercial

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 18 Open Source Vs Commercial
Open Source vs Commercial
atoms.text:
**[Open-source software (OSS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software)** is a type of computer software in which source code is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.

## When to use Open Source
Use Open Source:
- If someone has already created what you need.  
- When the code is well supported by its community. 
- When Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) is low 
- When it  aligns with what your brand stands for 
- When you need source code not just an application

atoms.title: Use commercial if
atoms.text:
**Commercial Software** is a software that is built by a person or group to be sold at a price. And depending on the software and price, source code may or may not be included.
## When to use Commercial Software
Use commercial software if:
- Total Cost of Ownership (TOC) is high for open source
- Security is a big concern 
- It is easier to adapt to your needs
- it is an Industry standard solution like spreadsheets everybody uses it 
- You need reliable support

question.prompt: Which of the following is false?

answers.text: You should not use the most popular commercial softwares because your competitor might also be using the same.
Support is not important because you can always train people to support functionalities and they can always solve problems for you.
TCO is an important factor even for Open Source versus Commercial.
You never need source code for the software you buy.

atoms.title: Cloud vs On-Prem Heading
atoms.text: # Cloud vs On-Prem

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 19 Cloud Vs On-Prem
Cloud vs On-Prem
atoms.text: **[Cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing)** is the on-demand availability of computer system resources, especially data storage and computing power, without direct active management by the user. The term is generally used to describe data centers available to many users over the Internet while **On-Prem or on-premise** is referred to as building and owning computing infrastructure within the physical confines of an enterprise.

atoms.title: When to Use Cloud text
atoms.text:
## Cloud 
You should use cloud computing if you need 
- Scalability & agility for quick deployments
- Accessibility from anywhere
- To have low infrastructure costs in the long term 
- Less control over security and compliance
- An always-available support model. 

Moving to cloud computing also frees up your resources, and you can focus on innovation.

atoms.title: When to use on prem text
atoms.text:
## On-prem
You might want to use op-prem if 
- Your total cost of ownership is lower
- Uptime is a concern, and your on-prem solution provides you with better uptime
- You want control and governance in your hands 
- When you have latency concerns because your data could be everywhere, across zones, on-prem, etc. 
- Egress is traffic going out of the ecosystem and ingress is traffic entering it
- If you need huge amounts of data to be transferred between cloud and on-prem constantly, i.e., ingress and egress are high, the cloud might be expensive for you.

### Additional resources
[On Premise vs. Cloud: Key Differences, Benefits and Risks](https://www.cleo.com/blog/knowledge-base-on-premise-vs-cloud)
[4 Reasons to Choose On-Premise vs. Cloud for Modern Workloads](https://www.itprotoday.com/cloud-computing/4-reasons-choose-premise-vs-cloud-modern-workloads)
[Cloud Vs On Premise Software: Which is Best For Your Business?](https://www.xperience-group.com/blog/cloud-vs-on-premise-software/)

question.prompt: Which of the following is not True?

answers.text: When it comes to cloud vs on-prem, cloud is the answer always because it is new and cool.
Cloud can be expensive if implementation is shoddy.
On-prem always offers better security features and control.
On-prem has been used for so long there must be some reasons, hence we should stick to on-prem.

atoms.title: In-house vs Outsource Heading
atoms.text: # In-house/Insource vs Outsource

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 20 In-House Vs Outsource
In-house vs Outsource
atoms.text:
Why does this matter in our case? 
Building and maintaining a data infrastructure is a huge task. There are various pieces to it. Sometimes you might want to own some parts, and you might want to outsource a few. Data needs a lot of massaging before it can be consumed. You might want to own some critical and strategic pieces. The long term of having inhouse expertise for such data infrastructure pieces could provide a competitive advantage. It might also help in retaining high-quality talent. Outsourcing pieces that do not offer you a competitive advantage might help you scale and focus on core business functions.   

Insourcing is doing a project with internal resources, while outsourcing is getting it done outside your company.

## Insource or Inhouse
You should insource when 
- Intellectual Property or IP must remain in-house
- When an understanding of culture and product is required
- When the work that needs to be done aligns with core business activities, and when the project deals with sensitive enterprise information such as security data.

## Outsource 
You should outsource when 
- A variety of skills are needed to complete the project. Outsourcing gives you access to a larger talent pool. 
- You should consider outsourcing when the work does not fall into the category of your core business function. 
- You should also consider outsourcing when you need to scale since it can be cost-effective.

question.prompt: When considering Insource or Outsource you should consider...

answers.text: Is it critical to your core business
Is it important that Intellectual property (IP) should remain with the company
A complete picture of the companies requirements to get the work done is needed
It will help in scaling and providing competitive advantage

atoms.title: Security and Compliance Header
atoms.text: # Security and Compliance

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 21 Security And Compliance
Security and Compliance
atoms.text:
### Security and Compliance
One of the most important aspects to keep in mind when building a data strategy is Data Security. There are many regulations and standards in today's world that have to be incorporated into a Data Strategy. If these are not addressed, your company will be open to huge fines for violations. Below you will find most of the critical items to consider, but remember that one of our stakeholders, Security and/or Legal, will help address compliance regulation.

### PII
**[PII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_data)**: "Personal data, also known as personal information or personally identifiable information (PII)is any information relating to an identifiable person." 

**Keep the following in mind when Handling PII:**
- Know local laws and definitions
- Identify where all PII is
    - **Data at rest**: Data that is stored in a storage device and is not actively used 
    - **Data in motion**: Data that is being used 
- Establish data retention policies
- Governance and controls

### PCI DSS
**[PCI DSS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_Card_Industry_Data_Security_Standard)**: "The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) is an information security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards from the major card schemes."

If you have PCI data, you need to follow stringent compliance guidelines, and there will be regular audits. If the procedures are not followed, there will be fines and legal ramifications.

**Core Control Objectives of PCI Data**
1. Build and Maintain a Secure Network and Systems
2. Protect Cardholder Data
3. Maintain a Vulnerability Management Program
4. Implement Strong Access Control Measures
5. Regularly Monitor and Test Networks
6. Maintain an Information Security Policy

### HIPAA
**[HIPAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Insurance_Portability_and_Accountability_Act)**- Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
**Protected Health Information (PHI)- medical record numbers, device identifiers and serial numbers. Any company or individual that comes into contact with PHI must enact and enforce appropriate policies, procedures, and safeguards to protect data.

**Violations lead to**:
- Termination from Job
- Sanctions from professional boards
- Criminal charges including fines and imprisonment


More information: [HIPAA for Dummies](https://www.hipaaguide.net/hipaa-for-dummies)

### GDPR
**[GDPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation)**: General Data Protection Regulation
- European Union and European Economic Area
- More control to citizens over their data
- Fines up to 20 Million Euros or 4% of global turnover
- Know what you have and why you have it?
- Where is the data, who uses it, and how is it used?
- Encryption is key
- Data Governance is highly recommended

### CCPA
**[CCPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Consumer_Privacy_Act)**: California Consumer Privacy Act

This act gives Californians the right 
- To know what personal information is being collected about them?
- To Know whether their personal information is sold or disclosed and to whom?
- To say no to the sale of personal information.
- To access their personal data.
- To have equal service and price, even if they exercise their privacy rights.

question.prompt: Which of the following are **not** true...

answers.text: PII could be a single identifier of a consumer or multiple fields put together, such as First name with phone.
Consumers are responsible for their PII, if they provide a company with PII information, the company can use it the way they want.
Only banks should care about PCI, small websites selling stuff on web donâ€™t need to bother about it
PCI just makes your life hard and does not provide any benefit

question.prompt: Which of the following are True.

answers.text: GDPR is only for European citizens so we do not have to be too cautious about data of customer residing outside Europe
The penalties are too heavy and that is the only reason we should comply with GDPR.
We might see regulations like GDPR coming from different parts of the world and hence we need to have a broader and stronger data compliance and data governance machinery.
It makes sense to follow good data practices, GDPR or no GDPR.

atoms.title: Knapsack Data Strategy MVP
tasks: Download the Knapsack Data Strategy MVP Proposal Template
Use your answers from the Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises spreadsheet and Data Infrastructure Strategy Exercises Template document to help you complete the MVP Proposal!
atoms.positive_feedback:
Great, now that you have completed this mini-project, please see the next page in the classroom for my solution. 

**As a reminder and as with just about all of the exercises in this course, Product Managers do not work in a vacuum and are part of a larger team who would normally provide input into the entire process. Therefore, your answers are subjective as are mine and it's ok if you came up with something different as long as you can back up your thoughts data and reason.**
atoms.description:
### Knapsack Data Strategy MVP
Before you complete your project for this course, you will be completing a mini project on Knapsack's Data strategy, which will help you to complete the final project. 

Your problem statement and template for the exercise is in **Knapsack Data Strategy MVP Proposal Template** from the lesson resources to complete the mini-project. This is where all of the hard work in all of the lesson exercises will pay off. You can and should use your answers from the exercises to help fill out your MVP for Knapsack. We have also provided an example solution in a separate file for this exercise.

atoms.title: Knapsack Solution
atoms.text:
#  Knapsack Data Strategy Proposal Solution
To see the solution, please download the *Solution Knapsack Data Strategy Proposal* found in the lesson resources. Thank you again for taking the time to complete this mini-project. You should now be prepared to complete the final project for this course!

atoms.title: Data Infrastructure Strategy Recap Heading
atoms.text: # Data Infrastructure Strategy Recap

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 22 Data Infrastructure Strategy Recap
Lesson Overview
atoms.text:
Based on what we covered during this lesson, you can now decide on processing pieces, strategize on when you need ETL and when you need ELT,  and you know all about data storage. 

You should be able to differentiate between a database, data warehouse or data lake and select the relevant data storage piece. You should be able to apply strategic nuances for making infrastructure decisions and security and compliance. You can now ensure that you are in compliance while dealing with various types of data. 

Great job getting through this lesson's content, next we'll wrap up the course!

atoms.title: Additional Resources
atoms.text:
## Key Terms and Additional Resources:
- **ETL stands for Extraction, Transformation and Loading** of data. In this type of processing pipeline, data is first extracted from various sources, after that transformed and loaded to a Database or Data Warehouse, from where it is pulled for analysis.
- **[Data processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_processing)** is, generally, the collection and manipulation of items of data to produce meaningful information.
- **[Data extraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_extraction)** is the act or process of retrieving data out of data sources for further data processing or data storage. 
- **In the [data transformation stage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load)**, a series of rules or functions are applied to the extracted data in order to prepare it for loading into the end target.
- **The load phase** loads the data into the end target, which can be any data store including a simple delimited flat file or a data warehouse. **Batch processing**Processing massive data with scheduled jobs at once is batch processing. 
- **Stream Processing** Another type of processing is done in almost real-time, as data comes it is processed.**Extraction, Loading and Transformation** In ELT, pipeline data can be extracted from various data sources, this data could be structured, unstructured or semi-structured data. Data is loaded in data storages such as Data Lake. Transformation is still required before data can be used. This happens after data has been loaded in Data Lake.
- **[database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database)** is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.
- **[data warehouse](https://aws.amazon.com/data-warehouse/)** is a central repository of information that can be analyzed to make better informed decisions. Data flows into a data warehouse from transactional systems, relational Database, and other sources, typically on a regular cadence.
- **[data lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_lake)** is a system or repository of data stored in its natural/raw format,usually object blobs or files. 
- **[Open-source software (OSS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software)** is a type of computer software in which source code is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.
- **Commercial Software** is a software that is built by a person or group to be sold at a price. And depending on software and price source code may or may not be included.
- **On-Prem or on-premise** is referred to building and owning computing infrastructure within the physical confines of an enterprise.
- **[Cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing)** is the on-demand availability of computer system resources, especially data storage and computing power, without direct active management by the user. 
- **Outsourcing** is getting it done outside your company.
- **Insourcing** is doing a project with internal resources.
- **Data at rest**: Data that is stored in storage device and is not actively used 
- **Data in motion**: Data that is being used 
- **[PII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_data)**: â€œPersonal data, also known as personal information or personally identifiable information (PII)is any information relating to an identifiable person.â€
- **[PCI DSS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_Card_Industry_Data_Security_Standard)]: â€œThe Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) is an information security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards from the major card schemes.â€
- **Protected Health Information (PHI)- medical record numbers, device identifiers and serial numbers. Any company or individual that comes into contact with PHI must enact and enforce appropriate policies, procedures and safeguards to protect data.
- **[HIPAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Insurance_Portability_and_Accountability_Act)**- Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
- **[GDPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation)**: General Data Protection Regulation
- **[CCPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Consumer_Privacy_Act)**: California Consumer Privacy Act

### Additional Resources
- [Uber: We under-invested in technology](https://www.zdnet.com/article/uber-we-under-invested-in-technology/)
- [Best open source projects from tech company giants](https://www.computerworld.com/article/3412219/best-open-source-projects-from-tech-company-giants.html)

atoms.title: Course Overview Header
atoms.text: # Course Overview

atoms.title: NDO30 DPMND C2 L4 23 Course Recap
Course Recap Text
atoms.text:
That's it! You are at the end of the course! I'm so glad you made it!

You are just about ready to be able to implement a data strategy in the real world. We've covered data pipelines, what data pipelines are as well as the components of data pipelines. Next, we talked about data consumers, types of data consumers, and data use cases of data consumers. After that, we covered data producers, types of data producers, and different types of data. In our last lesson, we applied a data strategy. In this section, we discussed data processing strategies, data storage choices, data infrastructure strategy, and security and compliance.


Now it's time to put all of your new knowledge and skills together to create a complete data strategy in the project for this course! Again, fantastic job making it through the content and exercises for the course!

atoms.title: Course Glossary
atoms.text:
| Term  | Definition |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|**API**:| An application program interface (API) is a set of routines, protocols, and tools for building software applications. Basically, an API specifies how software components should interact.|
|**Batch processing**:|Processing massive data with scheduled jobs at once is batch processing.|
|**[CCPA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Consumer_Privacy_Act)**:| California Consumer Privacy Act|
|**[Cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing)**| is the on-demand availability of computer system resources, especially data storage and computing power, without direct active management by the user.|
|**DBMS**:| Database Management System (also known as DBMS) is a software for storing and retrieving users' data by considering appropriate security measures. It allows users to create their own Database as per their requirement.|
|**[Data extraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_extraction)**| is the act or process of retrieving data out of data sources for further data processing or data storage.|
|**[data lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_lake)**| is a system or repository of data stored in its natural/raw format,usually object blobs or files.
|**[Data processing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_processing)**| is, generally, the collection and manipulation of items of data to produce meaningful information.|
|**[data warehouse](https://aws.amazon.com/data-warehouse/)**| is a central repository of information that can be analyzed to make better informed decisions. Data flows into a data warehouse from transactional systems, relational Database, and other sources, typically on a regular cadence.|
|**[Database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database)**| is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.|
|**[GDPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation)**:| General Data Protection Regulation|
|**Flat File**:| A flat file contains records that have no structured interrelationships. A flat file typically consists of a text file, from which all [word processing](https://searchwindowsserver.techtarget.com/definition/word-processor) or other structure characters or [markup](https://whatis.techtarget.com/definition/markup) has been removed.|
| **[HIPAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Insurance_Portability_and_Accountability_Act)**:| Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act|
|**[Open-source software (OSS)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software)**| is a type of computer software in which source code is released under a license in which the copyright holder grants users the rights to study, change, and distribute the software to anyone and for any purpose.|
|**[PCI DSS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payment_Card_Industry_Data_Security_Standard)**:| â€œThe Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) is an information security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards from the major card schemes.â€|
|**[PII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_data)**:| â€œPersonal data, also known as personal information or personally identifiable information (PII)is any information relating to an identifiable person.â€|
|**AI and ML**:| Artificial Intelligence means â€œmaking machines intelligent,â€ so they can make some decisions on their own according to the situations without the need for any human interference. And Machine Learning is â€œthe way to make those machines intelligent.â€ Machine learning is a subset of AI that focuses on a narrow range of activities.|
|**Batch Data Use-case**:| Batch processing requires separate programs for input, process, and output. Generally done for periodic data needs such as monthly, weekly, etc. An example is payroll and billing systems.|
|**Big Data**:| Big Data is described with the â€œthree Vsâ€, the volume of big-data is measured in terabytes or petabytes, the velocity at which data is generated is high and lastly it has a wide variety of sources such as text files, images, video, audio files, presentations, spreadsheets, email messages, and Database.|
|**Business Intelligence**:| Business Intelligence is a technology-driven process for analyzing data and presenting actionable information that helps executives, managers, and other corporate end-users make informed business decisions. Some common tools, SAP, Microsoft Power BI.|
|**Commercial Software**| is a software that is built by a person or group to be sold at a price. And depending on software and price source code may or may not be included.|
|**Data at rest**:| Data that is stored in storage device and is not actively used|
|**Data in motion**:| Data that is being used|
|**Data Normalization**:| Database normalization is the process of structuring a relational database following a series of so-called normal forms to reduce data redundancy and improve data integrity.|
|**Data Pipeline**:| A set of processes to move data from a source to destination, possibly transforming the data along the way.|
|**[In the data transformation stage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extract,_transform,_load)**|, a series of rules or functions are applied to the extracted data in order to prepare it for loading into the end target.|
|**Entity Attributes**:| Attributes are the properties that describe it, for a customer entity attributes could be Name, address, email, phone.|
|**Entity Data**:| Entity data is the data that  is stored in a table, for every entity there is a seperate table, and every table has columns that are attributes describing these entities. One row is dedicated to record one type of entity.|
|**Entity**:| Entity is a unique object such as customer, product, order etc.|
|**Extraction, Loading and Transformation**| In ELT, pipeline data can be extracted from various data sources, this data could be structured, unstructured or semi-structured data. Data is loaded in data storages such as Data Lake. Transformation is still required before data can be used. This happens after data has been loaded in Data Lake.|
|**ETL stands for Extraction, Transformation and Loading**| of data. In this type of processing pipeline, data is first extracted from various sources, after that transformed and loaded to a Database or Data Warehouse, from where it is pulled for analysis.|
|**Event Data**:| Event data is generated by actions that happen in an application. The scale at which event data is generated is much larger compared to entity data. For every one user using the app, there could be thousands of events. Server logs also generate event data.|
|**Foreign Key**:| A foreign key is a set of one or more columns that refer to a primary key in another table. A table can have one or more foreign keys. Foreign keys can contain duplicates and can have null values.|
|**Insourcing**| is doing a project with internal resources.|
|**IoT**:| The Internet of Things (IoT) is a system of interrelated computing devices, mechanical and digital machines, objects, animals, or people that are provided with unique identifiers (UIDs) and the ability to transfer data over a network without requiring human-to-human or human-to-computer interaction.|
|**Key**:| A key is an index to a record in a table.|
| **Normalization**:| Normalization refers to eliminating redundancy. Each table should have data around a specific topic. This eliminates modification complexities and saves on storage.|
|**On-Prem or on-premise**| is referred to building and owning computing infrastructure within the physical confines of an enterprise.|
|**Outsourcing**| is getting it done outside your company.|
|**Primary Key**:| Primary keys are unique identifiers for a record in a table. There is only one primary key in a table. Primary key column cannot be blank or null.|
|**Protected Health Information (PHI)**:| medical record numbers, device identifiers and serial numbers. Any company or individual that comes into contact with PHI must enact and enforce appropriate policies, procedures and safeguards to protect data.|
|**QuickBooks**|: QuickBooks is an accounting software geared mainly toward small and medium-sized businesses and offers on-premises accounting applications as well as cloud-based versions that accept business payments, manage and pay bills, and payroll functions.|
|**Real-Time Data Use-case**|: Real-time data processing involves a continual input, process, and output of data. Data must be processed in a small time period (or near real-time).|
|**Relational Modeling**:|  Relational modeling is forming relationships between data tables.|
|**Reporting**:| A report is a document that presents information in an organized format for a specific audience and purpose. Although summaries of reports may be delivered orally, complete reports are almost always in the form of written documents. Business reporting or enterprise reporting refers to both "the public reporting of operating and financial data by a business enterprise, and "the regular provision of information to decision-makers within an organization to support them in their work. Some common tools are Sap Crystal Reports, Zoho.|
|**SaaS**:| Software as a service (SaaS) is a software distribution model in which a third-party provider hosts applications and makes them available to customers over the Internet.|
|**Salesforce**:| Salesforce is a customer relationship management solution.|
|**Schema**:| A data schema is a structure for organizing and classifying data in a database. It defines both the data contents and relationships.|
|**Slack**:| Slack is a cloud-based proprietary instant messaging platform developed by Slack Technologies.|
|**Stream Processing**:| Another type of processing is done in almost real-time, as data comes it is processed.|
|**Stripe**:| Stripe is online payment processing for internet businesses. It allows individuals and companies to make and receive payments over the Internet.|
|**The load phase**| loads the data into the end target, which can be any data store including a simple delimited flat file or a data warehouse.|
|**Use-case**:| A specific situation in which a product or service could potentially be used.|
|**Visualization**:| Data visualization is the graphical representation of information and data. By using visual elements like charts, graphs, and maps, data visualization tools provide an accessible way to see and understand trends, outliers, and patterns in data. Some common tools are Tableau, QlikView.|
